IRS990.ActivityOrMissionDescription: To foster the organization and development of a strong, community- based Federation which conducts cost-effective workplace giving campaigns on behalf of member health charities.
IRS990.MissionDescription: The mission of Community Health Charities of Colorado is to foster the organization and development of a strong, community-based Federation which conducts cost-effective workplace giving campaigns on behalf of member health charities to raise needed funds for medical research, education and patient services.
IRS990.Description: Distribution of Contributions: CHC raises, collects, and distributes contributions to member agencies and donor-designated non-member charities.

Activity2.Description: Community Service: CHC provides referrals, information and education to the community about Community Health Charities (CHC) and CHC's non-profit member agencies. Development: CHC cultivates and manages workplace employee giving programs for the purpose of raising, collecting and distributing contributions to non-profit member agencies to support their missions and operations. Agency Relations: CHC provides information services to, and promotes collaboration among member agencies to ensure their continued well-being, participation and membership. Management of Public Sector Campaign: CHC serves as the contract manager of the Denver Employees Combined Campaign, which facilitates charitable giving among City and County of Denver employees.

Form990ScheduleDPartXIV.Explanation: The Organization adopted guidance related to uncertainty in income taxes on July 1, 2009. After evaluating the tax positions taken, none are considered to be uncertain, including its qualification as a not-for-profit under 501(c)(3); therefore, no income tax liabilities have been recognized as of June 30, 2010. If incurred, interest and penalties associated with tax positions are recorded in the period assessed as general and administrative expense. No interest or penalties have been assessed as of June 30, 2010. Tax years that remain subject to examination include 2007 through the current year.

Sickle Cell Disease Assoc of Amer

Form990ScheduleIPartIV.Identifier: Monitoring the Use of Grant Funds
Form990ScheduleIPartIV.Explanation: The organization does not provide grant funds. CHC is a federation that collects and distributes contributions, largely from employer payroll deduction campaigns, to its non-profit member agencies.

GeneralExplanation.Explanation: The organization's finance committee thoroughly reviews the 990 and the annual audit and recommends them for approval to the full board. Upon review and approval by the board, the Form 990 is signed by the Board Chair and filed with the IRS.

The organization's conflict of interest policy is reviewed annually and all Board members and staff are required to disclose any potential interests and sign the policy for the calendar year. Board members and staff are asked to review their status and report any changes at each board meeting.

Compensation for the position of President/CEO is recommended to the full Board by a Board committee using The Colorado Nonprofit Association bi-annual Salary Survey and the Mountain States Employers Council's Compensation and Benefits Survey. Compensation for all other employees is determined by the President/CEO based upon performance appraisal and industry standards and recommended to the Board through the annual budgeting process.
The organization makes its articles of incorporation, bylaws, board-approved policies and financial statements available to the public upon request.

GeneralExplanation.ReturnReference: Part I, Line 22 & Part X, Line 27
GeneralExplanation.Explanation: The balance of net assets at the beginning of the year (July 1, 2009) has been restated to correct capital leases for equipment that were improperly recorded, and to adjust campaign revenue for the overstatement of distributions payable. The restatement resulted in an increase in the previously reported balance of net assets as of July 1, 2009, of $268,462.

The Executive Committee of the Corporation is comprised of the following board members: Chair, Vice Chair, Secretary, Treasurer, immediate past Chair, and up to four additional board members approved by the Board of Directors. The President/CEO shall serve as a non-voting member of the Executive Committee. All members of the executive committee are members of the board. Active direction and control of the business and affairs of the corporation are subject to the overall guidance and supervision of the Board of Directors. Two members of the Executive Committee may sign any deeds, mortgages, bonds, contracts, or other instruments which the Board of Directors has authorized to be executed, except in cases where the signing and execution thereof shall be expressly delegated by the Board of Directors or by the Bylaws or by statute to some other officer or agent of the Corporation. The Executive Committee shall be responsible for governance of the Corporation, subject to Board ratification and, between meetings of the Board, shall act for the Board in connection with the operations of the Corporation. Upon a finding of necessity, the Executive Committee may make appropriations, or recommend modifications or amendments to policies or procedures. The Executive Committee shall have such other powers as assigned by the Board of Directors.

GeneralExplanation.Identifier: Classes and Voting Rights of Members
GeneralExplanation.Explanation: Line 6: The organization has one class of member agencies. Line 7a: Each member agency has the right to one vote in the election of each member of the Board of Directors. Line 7b: Any amendments to the organization's By-laws or Articles of Incorporation are subject to the approval of at least two-thirds of the member agencies.
